Episode.Title: Bartlet's Third State of the Union

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: 8:54 P.M. Staffers, including Mrs. Landingham, quickly move through the office. Sam paces nervously, waiting on the phone.

Dialogues.Line: We are, by my watch, six minutes away from President Bartlet's entrance onto the floor of the House of Representatives. This is his third State of the Union Address. The familiar introduction by the Doorkeeper of the House, Edgar Finney. Perhaps some people don't know that in order for the President to address Congress, he must first receive permission from the Speaker...
[into phone] I'm still here. [glances at his watch] All right. [pause] Is that a yes? Is it a yes? Toby and Ginger rush by.
Sam...
[to Toby] Be half a minute. Toby and Ginger exit to THE OVAL OFFICE. Leo and a crowd of staffers are standing inside.
Mr. Pettit?
Yeah.
Delete 'vigorously' from the first sentence.
Which paragraph?
We're not going to vigorously pursue campaign finance reform?
No, we're just gonna pursue it regularly.
Not vigorously.
Not tonight. [to Leo] McGowan says we're fine. He feels the word 'vigorously''s inflammatory. [to staffers] Change chokehold to tight grip.
Is that it?
Yeah.
No, Sam's still on it.
We got like four minutes, Toby. Bartlet enters, rolling down his sleeves. Charlie follows.
Where are we?
Sam's still on.
Bob Novak just said this was the speech of my political life. You know how many times I've heard that?
Sir, Senator McGowan say's we're fine if we cut 'vigorously.'
Do it.
How you feeling?
Good. Bartlet looks nervous as Charlie helps him on with his suit jacket.
Abbey's already in her seat?
Yes sir.
[to Charlie] I said, my wife's in her seat?
Yes sir.
We got four minutes.
We'll get him in the car. Let's go. Bartlet looks up and follows Leo out.
Here we go. The crowd follows Bartlet out to the OUTER OVAL OFFICE.
[into phone] I'm gonna tell him it's a yes. [pumps fist in air] Thank you. [hangs up as they walk by]
What did they say?
[joins the crowd] We put our weight behind Sp 380. It's a highway improvement bill. They all walk out to the HALLWAY.
What else?
Set aside some U.S. park land...
What else?
That's it.
I want to be clear. This is the understanding that we build him a highway and name a park after him and we have the support for the Blue Ribbon?
Yep.
Mr. President...
Do it.
Ginger!
Yeah?
Tell C.J. the green light on the Blue Ribbon. She'll know what it means.
Yes sir. [takes off]
[to Toby] We'll write in the car! The crowd exits to the NORTH ENTRANCE. Several limousines are parked in a motorcade. Sam and Toby walk to the front limo.
Sir...
Yeah.
It's a good thing.
The Blue Ribbon...
Yeah.
Yeah. Leo, Bartlet and Charlie enter the middle car. The rest of the them enter the rear car.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NATIONAL STRATEGIES GROUP - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: 8:57 P.M. Josh paces nervously in a room full of computers and phones. He spies a phone pollster.

Dialogues.Line: Excuse me... What are you doing?
I'm just...
You were putting gum in your mouth?
Yeah, cause that's what I...
'Cause that's a good idea to be chewing gum when you're taking a poll for the President of the United States. That's the sound people like to hear over the phone.
The poling hasn't started yet.
Well, thank you... Mr. Helper. Donna walks by, rescuing the callers.
Josh.
Yeah.
[smiling] These people have done this before.
They're not our people.
They're Joey Lucas' people.
None of them have accents?
They're all out of the Midwest.
I'm saying Joey Lucas is deaf. She would have NO way of knowing... [suddenly turns, yelling] Do any of you people have accents?
Oh my God... Donna turns away embarrassed. The crowd stares at Josh.
Do any of you people have the power of speech?
They're fine. Josh turns away and nervously looks at his watch.
I should be there right now. He walks off with Donna in tow.
He's fine!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. WASHINGTON DC STREET- NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The motorcade rushes down the street flanked by Police escort.

Dialogues.Line: Therefore I am asking the leaders of Congress...
NIGHT Leo is on the phone...
[into phone] "...the members of both parties to join me in establishing a Blue Ribbon National Commission to fashion..."
[nodding] Yeah
[into phone] I want it for him when he walks in the door.
Gail Schumer, should we expect the White House to be doing...
NIGHT Several reporters mill around the Press Room. Through the partition we see
conducting a briefing to a room full of reporters.
...it's own polling?
You'd better believe it. This may well be the speech of the President's political life.
Excuse Me. I've got a heads up! There'll be a last minute addition.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: The President will be announcing a bipartisan Blue Ribbon Commission to study the long-term future Entitlements Programs. Obviously there will be more details in the address.
Why last minute?
You know when I say 'last minute' I'm wrong. We're just under three minutes.
C.J... why last minute?
It's something he's been going back and forth on. He wanted to make sure he had the support of the Democratic leadership.
And he does?
Yes. I also wanted to remind you that "Capital Beat" will be broadcasting live from the West Wing for the two or three hours following the address so that area is off limits for carousing.
Capital Beat is doing live post game from the White House?
Yes.
So why do they get special treatment?
Because they're special. Enjoy the show everybody. [exits]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. CAPITOL BUILDING - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: Those of us in the future will demand boldly putting aside our partisan...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. CAPITOL HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby and Sam are hunched over a counter in the hallway.

Dialogues.Line: ...blunders and abandoning our ideological... what?
Entrenchment.
Those of us in the future will demand boldly putting aside our partisan blinders and abandoning our ideological... entrenchment.
Yeah.
[sighs] That's it.
Okay.
This is it.
Yeah. Sam hands the copy to a staffer.
[sighs] Phone it to the Prompter. The staffer walks down the hall and pauses to speak into his cell phone. As he does, the Presidential Entourage passes.
Mr. President. Bartlet stoops to tie his shoelace. Sam, Toby and Leo glance at each other nervously.
Mr. President. Toby hands Bartlet the speech in a leather portfolio.

Thanks. Bartlet shakes Toby and Sam's hands. Staffers applaud as the group walks down the HALLWAY to the chambers. Bartlet tries to hide his nervousness. At the ENTRANCE to the chambers stands an elderly gentleman. They nod to each other.
Sir. Bartlet pauses, bows his head and prays.
[crossing himself] Amen.
Amen.
Mr. Finney, would you tell the Speaker I'd like to see him please? Mr. Finney nods then turns and enters the chamber. We hear the murmur of the crowd and the sound of the gavel...
Mr. Speaker... The President of the United States. Bartlet enters the chamber leaving Sam, Toby, and Leo standing proudly.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: EXT. WASHINGTON D.C. - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: ...continue to rise through every age...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NATIONAL STRATEGIES GROUP - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh and Donna sit on a stairway watching the address on a monitor. They are surrounded by callers.

Dialogues.Line: ...against every challenge, of people of great works and greater possibilities who have always, always found the wisdom and strength to come together as one nation; to widen the circle of opportunity, to deepen the meaning of our freedom, to form a more perfect union. Our best days lie ahead. God bless you and God bless the United State of America! The crowd erupts into applause. Josh stands, hollering and clapping. Donna stands smiling.
[to Donna] Tell me about it.
He was brilliant up there.
Up there is where this President eats! That is his place of business. Yes, he did well. Josh and Donna walk down the STAIRS to the main floor.
Yeah.
Let's find out how well.
This is exciting.
Yeah.
Yeah.
So, what do I do?
What do you mean?
What do I tell them?
Tell them to start
Didn't you talk to Joey?
Yeah.
What did she say?
She said her plane was late.
[confused] What did she say I should tell the callers?
She didn't say anything.
Donna!
Tell them to start, Josh.
They're not supposed to receive special instructions based on...
What?
Time zones!? I don't know. I'm... I'm not a pollster. I thought Joey called.
She called from the plane and said she was late.
When is she gonna be here?
Joshua Lyman, you have the cutest little butt in professional politics. Josh turns to find Joey standing with a big grin on her face. Next to her is her interpreter, Kenny.
Kenny, really, that better been her talking.
I'm here.
Where the hell you been?
My plane had mechanical difficulties.
This is the State of the Union. There was nothing you could do about it?
No. Because as a child I never paid attention during airplane mechanics class.
Is this the kind of Noel Cowardesque wit I can expect all night long?
Yes.
I want to start the phone banks. They need instructions. Joey and Kenny walk towards the crowd.
Is anyone chewing gum?
No! Josh glares at Donna, who ignores him.
Okay... start! Joey looks smugly at Josh.
I had already taken care of the gum thing...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WEST WING LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The lobby is transformed into a set for "Capital Beat". Staffers stand by behind the scenes watching.

Dialogues.Line: In five... four... three...
Live... from the White House... it's Capital Beat with Mark Gottfried. Tonight on Capital Beat a special expanded edition... The State of the Union.

Good evening. I'm Mark Gottfried and tonight our show is live from the White House. We'll be joined all night long by Republicans and Democrats, lawmakers and pundants, and we'll be talking... Sitting behind a table on stage is host, Mark Gottfried, C.J., and Congressman Henry Shallick.

...to focus groups around the country. On the panel with me right now is Deputy House Majority Whip, Henry Shallick and the very lovely, very talented Miss Claudia Jean Cregg, White House Press Secretary. C.J., on a scale of 1 to 10, how did the President do tonight?

[beaming with happiness] 14. You know, Mark, the President is a commanding public speaker and the bar is usually set quite a bit higher when it's a major address but tonight he cleared it with room to spare.
My official tally has him interrupted for applause 73 times.
I have 72 times but I'll take your count.
Henry Shallick, how did the President do tonight?

Well, C.J.'s right. The President is a gifted public speaker. We've always known that, and it's an admirable quality... not unlike juggling. Now if he had only said something. C.J. and Mark smile at each other.
By my count, 23 of the interruptions for applause were for co-opted Republican ideas.

Let's take a quick break. We're just getting started with our post game analysis of President Bartlet's Third State of the Union address. We've got guests standing by around the country. We'll be back with more Capital Beat right after this.
We're out.
[into the camera] C.J.'s not wearing any pants.
Yes...
No pants whatsoever.
It's cable! Carol...
90 seconds back.
[walks up to C.J.] Can I see you a moment?
Yeah.
Can I see you over there?
Can we do it here?
Why?
I'm not wearing any pants. Can we do it here?
Sure, we're fine here as long as there aren't any microphones or cameras around.
Carol!
Yeah. [runs up and hands her a robe]
Thank you.
You look like a Rockette.
Yeah.
Yeah.
[ties the robe around her waist] You know why I'm not wearing any pants?
I just assumed it was the usual reason. They walk off stage.
I sat in paint.
60 seconds back.
After the speech I went to the sculpture garden to get some air and take it in and sat on a bench.
And it didn't say wet paint?
It did it turns out, but...
[runs up] How's it coming?
Where'd you get the bathrobe?
The Gym.
They have bathrobes at the gym?
In the women's locker room.
But not the men's.
Yeah.
Now, that's outrageous. There's a thousand men working here and 50 women...
Yeah, and it's the bathrobe's that's outrageous.
30 seconds.
What's going on?
Jack Sloane has an official reprimand in his jacket.
For what?
Excessive force.
[looks angry] How long ago?
17 years ago. There was a criminal charge... it was dismissed. There was a civil suit... it was dismissed. There was enormous community and political pressure from local Black Democrats.
Our people?
17 years ago...
15 seconds.
Okay, so they gave him an official condemnation.
Yeah.
Does anyone have the story yet?
They will.
10 seconds. C.J. runs back to the stage. Sam and Carol follow her.
I need to see the Police Officer. What was his name?
Sloane! C.J. tears off the robe and tosses it to Carol.
Right! [sits down and puts on her mike]
Take the desk away and I'd pick up three share points.
In five... four... three...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Mrs. Landingham stands watching the T.V. Charlie walks in.

Dialogues.Line: [on T.V.] We're back with out panel including Deputy House Majority Whip Henry Shallick and White House Pres Secretary C.J. Cregg.
Welcome back.
How'd it look on TV?
It looked good. Charlie, is it possible that C.J. isn't wearing any pants right now?
Yeah. She sat in wet paint.
And she's not wearing any pants?
Well, she's wearing underwear Mrs. Landingham. She hasn't gone smokeless.
Okay. Mrs. Landingham turns off the T.V. and sits behind her desk. Charlie takes out a slip of paper.
I didn't understand this note.

The President was balancing his checkbook and came across an outstanding check for $500 that was never cashed. A check was written by the First Lady to a woman the President has never heard of and he would like you to ask her about it.
The President was balancing his checkbook?
Yeah.
Why?
He does it to relax.
Okay.
Yeah.
And why doesn't he ask the First lady about the $500 check himself in the normal course of, you know, being married to her.
When the President inquires into the First lady's personal bookkeeping, the First Lady gets angry at him... and yells.
Well, she's gonna get angry and yell when I inquire too.
Well, the President doesn't care so much about that. [smiles]
Yeah, okay. This is a good job. [walks out]
I saw you on T.V.!
Cool.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Abbey stands in the room watching the speech on tape. She rewinds...

Dialogues.Line: To build this new future will demand boldly setting aside our partisan blinders and abandoning our ideological entrenchment. [applause] Therefore, I am asking the leaders of Congress and members of both parties to join me in establishing a Blue Ribbon National Commission to [applause] fashion... She rewinds.
...boldly setting aside our partisan blinders and abandoning our ideological entrenchment. [applause] There is a knock at the door.
Come in!
Therefore, I am asking the leaders of Congress and members of both parties to join me in establishing a Blue Ribbon National Commission to [applause] fashion...
[enters] Mrs. Bartlet? She turns off the TV.
Hey, Charlie.
Am I disturbing you?
I just came up to change my clothes.
Did you sit in paint?
I'm sorry?
C.J. sat in wet paint.
In the Sculpture Garden?
Yeah.
No. I'm not supposed to go to the reception in the same clothes in which I went to the speech.
Yeah.
I could just tell people that I have two outfits exactly alike.
That's what I do.
[smiles] What do you need?
Ma'am, I'd like you to bear in mind that I'm not wearing pads, or a helmet or contact gear of any kind. A $500 check that hasn't been cashed. It's written to named...
Oh, how long has that been up his ass?!
Well I wouldn't know ma'am, but...
[angry] Her name is Jane Robinson. I read an article about her a few months ago.
Her husband threw her out...
He set fire to the bed.
And she bought the kids Christmas presents early and they were ruined.
So I sent her $500.
Well, she hasn't cashed it. I'll make sure it got to her.
Thank you.
Thank you, Ma'am Charlie leaves quickly. Abbey sits in the bed, turning the TV back on.
...me in establishing a Blue Ribbon National Commission...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sound of party music.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. RECEPTION HALL - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: A reception room is brightly lit and filled with party guests. Music is playing while waiters circulate with drinks and noshes.

Dialogues.Line: Hey! Sam Seaborn, everybody! Sam enters the party to applause.
See? You guys said I couldn't write comedy. Sam spots Leo in the middle of the room.
You talk to C.J.?
Yeah.
The Dial-up groups are huge... middle class tax cuts, Social Security.
What about polling?
Josh and Joey will have early numbers in an hour. My point is this police officer... The President pointed to him and asked him to stand. Margaret [walks up] Leo.
Let C.J. talk to him.
Is he here?
Yeah.
No pictures anywhere near the President.
Yeah. [walks off]
They need you in the Situation Room. [walks away with Leo]
NIGHT A group of people in suits and uniforms are assembled around the table as Leo enters.
What's going on?
Leo, we believe 5 DEA Agents have been abducted in Columbia.
Where?
On a road between Bogot. and a training base in Puente Mayo.
Was it the C.R.F?
We don't know.
Do we think it was the C.R.F?
Yeah.
Can the Agents be identified as U.S. Drug Enforcement?
They're carrying badges.
From Bogot. to Puente Mayo? They're gonna shoot these guys.
Leo, I have...

All I know is the Press Corps's upstairs and there's a live TV show being broadcasting next door. [to Marine Officer] I need to meet with State, Justice, and the Pentagon... and it needs to happen softly.
Yes sir. Leo sits down at the table and shuffles through the folders.
This was almost a good night.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sounds of people talking on the phone.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NATIONAL STRATEGIES GROUP - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Joey and Kenny circulate through the Calling Bank. Donna is standing nearby.

Dialogues.Line: Donna!
Yeah?
It's going well. It's a 17% response rate.
Great.
[walks up] Jack Sloane was reprimanded for excessive violence by the Detroit Police Department.
How long ago?
17 years.
What happened?
I don't know. He made a bust. He broke the guys leg. The DA couldn't make a case. The civil suit was dismissed but it's there.
Who's Jack Sloane?
From tonight. Joey looks confused.
The police officer.
I wasn't there. I was on a plane with mechanical difficulties...
Officer Jack Sloane of the Detroit Police Department was added at the last minute to the invited guests that are recognized by the President at the speech.
He was the off-duty cop who...
At the Elementary School?
Yeah.
He wasn't vetted?
[starts pacing] It was last minute. When do I see numbers?
Joey says it's going good.
Great! When do I see numbers?
There's a 17% response rate.
Fantastic. When do I see numbers?
You need patience, Joshua!
I need numbers, Tonto!
The poll's an hour old!
You get early numbers....
When I get them, you'll have them.
So, what do you do in the meantime?
I'm getting a doughnut. [walks off]
Okay. Josh watches them walk off. He sighs and wanders over to a desk. Donna follows.

I'm plagued by this nonsense Donna. I swear, it's just reaching epidemic proportions. Those numbers are gonna show we had a big night and the balance is gonna be dragged down by a news cycle that won't shake the cops. [sits]
You should ask her out.
I'm sorry?
You should ask Joey out. Tonight could be the night.
The night to do what?
To ask her out.
Get a doughnut!
Okay. Donna wanders off. Josh grabs his phone.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Margaret wanders past a monitor on the way to the Lobby.

Dialogues.Line: Before we go to commercial again just let me ask for predictions. How big a bump does the President get on this speech? She approaches a small group of people laughing. One is MICKEY TROOP, the Secretary of State.
Excuse me, Mr. Secretary?
Yes?
I'm sorry for interrupting but LEO McGarry was wondering if you could come say hello to an old friend of his.
Certainly. Would you excuse me please? They wander off.
Sit Room.
Thank you. [puts his drink down]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SITUATION ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The group is sitting around the table.

Dialogues.Line: Are we verifying exactly who was at the Lab?
We verified Agents McGraff and Nunn, but we still can't verify the other three.
I don't want to misnotify the families.
[comes in and sits] Leo.
Mickey, 2:00 P.M. local time in Bogot., 5 DEA Agents assisting police in evidence gathering at a cocaine lab were taken by the CRF.
Are they alive?
We think so.
Okay. Puente Mayo is an Affronte stronghold. The C lab the Agents grabbed was one of their top producing cocaine labs. I'm gonna open a dialog... we're gonna do it with one of their own commanders.
Who are they talking too?
They'll tell us but I think it's gonna be Nelson Guerra. He's a friend of Jeffe.
Get me everything on him.
Yes, sir.
Is there anybody close by on the ground?
The closest we've got is Tres Encinas.
Who's there?
6 Commanders and 13 support.
Really.
Yeah.
How many people are gonna be guarding wherever these guys are being taken too?
Five, six hundred.
Not the numbers you're hoping for if you're contemplating a massive attack and rescue mission.
No.
Tell Special Operations Command at Ft. Bragg to submit three plans for a unilateral op. They have an hour.
Yes, sir.
[stands] We should let these 19 guys at Tres Encinas know they're in it now too.
Yes, sir. Leo walks out.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WEST WING LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: This time on the Capitol Beat dais are Ainsley Hayes and GRETCHEN TYLER of the ACLU.

Dialogues.Line: I challenge all our schools to teach character education. To teach values. To teach citizenship. If it means our kids will pay more attention to mathematics, and English literature, and history, and science, and the arts, and less attention to designer labels, [applause] Then our public schools should be able to require students to wear school uniforms.

School uniforms from a liberal democrat. What was the sound we just heard? [laughs] Joining us now on our panel is Associate White House Counsel Ainsley Hayes. To my left, Gretchen Tyler, Director of Public Education for the ACLU. Gretchen let's start with you. Were you surprised?
I was surprised, Mark. I was disappointed. This President has always had strong 1st Amendment credentials.
What's the position of the ACLU?
The position of the ACLU is that every child in the country has the legal right to public education. And that can't be conditioned on compliance with a uniform policy.
Ainsley?
I think Gretchen's point is well taken and...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS BULLPEN - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Staffers stand around in the Communications Bullpen watching a TV. Sam is among them.

Dialogues.Line: ...in that I'm' not 100% sure what the President suggested tonight is Constitutional. What I can tell you is that he is concerned about the kids left out... Sam looks unhappy and sighs.
...because they can't afford the clothes some of their friends wear. Sam walks out to the HALLWAY into the LOBBY.

He's also taken serious note of any number of studies done by educational experts that show by and large kids will do better wearing uniforms. A guard opens the door to the LOBBY. Sam enters and stands off stage.
It should be noted that there already are dress restrictions on public school kids. They're not allowed to wear inappropriate clothing or wear something obscene on their t-shirts.
It should also be noted that those restrictions were over the strong objection of the ACLU.
Ainsley, gauge for us how strongly the President feels about this.
Well, he included it in his State of the Union Address.
But, from your conversations with him personally.
Oh, I haven't' had any conversations with him personally.
On this.
On anything. I've never met him. I'm an Associate Counsel. The Chinese food guy's got more access than I do.
[surprised] And yet they have you out here speaking for the White House.
Yeah! [smiles] It's a really big night for me. [laughs]
All right. We'll be back with Gretchen Tyler and Ainsley Hayes and more guests as the night goes on. We're going to send you to New York for some other news. Stay with us. Here's Frank and Judy.
We're out.
[to Ainsley] You crack me up.
[laughs] Thank you.
Hey, Gracie...
Hey, Sam! [takes off her mike]
Mark, she have time?
It's a five-minute newsbreak. Ainsley leaves the stage and follows Sam.
[smiles] Have you been watching?
Yes.
Aren't I delightful?
Yes. They exit to the HALLWAY.
You know what I'd like? I'd like if you didn't say you weren't 100% sure the President's proposal isn't Constitutional.
The ACLU has a reasonable case to make against the President.
They did a fine job of making it's without the help of the President's lawyer. They both walk into SAM'S OFFICE.
That's a fair point!
How have you never met the President?
I haven't.
You've been working here 3 months.
He works in the Oval Office and I work in the Steam pipe Trunk Distribution Venue. I can't believe we've haven't run into each other.
I'll set up an introduction.
No.
You can meet him tonight.
No way.
It's no problem.
Yes, it is.
[looks smug] Are you scared to meet the President?
I'm not scared to meet the President.
Yeah, you are.
I am not scared to meet the President cause I'm not gonna meet the President.
Ainsley...

[whining] I'm having a good night. I just want to keep having a good night. I don't want to live in fear of the inevitable bumbling of the English language that will occur and the mortification that will ensue.
That sounds pretty bad.
[stammers] I am... yes... I am indeed... Yes, I am scared to meet the President.
And that sounds really bad.
Yes.
Okay, well when you meet him, you meet him.
No need to rush that day. [walks out]
Right. [runs after her] Okay, can I talk to you about adrenaline for a second?
Adrenaline?
Yeah. You're feeling it right now and it's gonna get even more cause it's a big night, and you were a hit and you've never experienced anything like this. They stand outside the LOBBY.
And you think I'm going to have a nutty.
I'm saying don't drink until you're off television.
God! Thanks Sam for that debating tip. You have a feel for nuances. You say I shouldn't be drunk when I'm representing the White House.
Yeah. And remember you're a blond, republican girl and that nobody likes you.
I'm going back on television now.
Try to remember you're on our side. Ainsley reenters the lobby and Sam walks off.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. RECEPTION HALL - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Abbey stands on a stage in front of the guests. The crowd is laughing.

Dialogues.Line: Thank you. Thank you. Sam Seaborn wrote that line for me. You know, there's a lot of polling going on right now. The Instant Dial-Up Focus groups predict tonight's speech was a success. [applause] And I'm sure where Josh is over at the phone banks they'll be confirming that. But, when the numbers are crunched and the polls are taken I think everyone here realizes that the truly important thing is that I changed my hair. [laughter] Seriously, um, this is not my official toast. My official toast is later. I just wanted to say informally before the President got here. Thank you so much for your hard work and enjoy tonight's success. Abbey toasts the crowd and steps off the stage. Leo walks up.
[quietly] Your hair looks great by the way.
That's great. So, what's going on with Jack Sloane?
C.J.'s on it. So, we were able to get the language in about the Blue Ribbon Commission.
Yeah. They stop walking.
We were able to get it in at the last minute. We got our guys who changed the language to broaden the...
[angry] I was there, Leo.
We changed the language at the last minute, Abbey. If you want to be pissed at someone, the architect of...
I don't want to be pissed at anyone but thanks for asking. And I don't need to be told who the architect of tonight's speech was. Toby enters to applause and handshakes.
Toby Ziegler! Abbey leaves Leo and approaches Toby with a forced smile of her face. He leans in close as they shake hands.
I want to see you in your office in half an hour. Got it?
Yes, Ma'am. [looks around uncomfortably]
Keep shaking hands. Photographers snap their pictures as Toby and Abbey shake hands.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: Hang on...
Congressman, he didn't say that. You weren't listening.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NATIONAL STRATEGIES GROUP - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh sits on a couch rapidly thumbing through "Vogue." A T.V. is playing Capitol Beat. On the dais are Ainsley and a congressman.

Dialogues.Line: He said...
What he said what that standardized testing would be more acceptable if these vast limitations were understood.
What about the New York City testing scores that Hal Jaffe just cited a while ago? Josh glances at the T.V. and tosses away a magazine insert.
Six out of ten were black or Hispanic.
...forgot to mention was that six out of 10 of those New York City students were either black or Hispanic. Donna leans over the back of the couch.
Right on the button.
So Josh...
No.
Are you still thinking?
We're still doing this?
Have you asked her out yet?
Donna...
Cause the last time I asked you you hadn't asked her out yet.
What is taking so long? [gets up and paces]

'Joey, would you like to go out Friday night.' You know, you have to say it. You have to ask a girl out on a date. You can't just randomly tumble into a girl sideways and hopes she breaks up with you soon like you always do. [sits down at a desk]
Why not?
Cause you can't!
You just said I always do.
Josh, I can help you or not help you. It's up to you.
Then I absolutely choose NOT helping me.
You want me to ask her out for you? Joey and Kenny walk by.
Yeah. That's exactly what I want you to do.
Joey... [gets up]
Sit down. [Both sit.] Where are the first numbers?
Soon.
How soon?
Five minutes.
You said five minutes 15 minutes ago!
The response rate slowed down.
Why?
People are going to bed.
Yeah, but the response rate didn't stop, right? Not everyone went to bed. If they did that would be phenomenal. It would be a phenomenon!
The response rate slowed down and you need to have some juice and crackers.
America is talking and I'm trying to hear what they're saying.
They're saying that you're an egomaniac who needs to know the public loves you and that you'll have the numbers in five minutes.
Well, I don't think that is what they're saying but absent any other information...
[frustrated] Josh...
Joey, it's the State of the Union. We worked on this speech for three months!
You will hear America speak...
In five minutes.
In five minutes. As Josh sighs, there is a loud bang and the entire block is plunged into darkness. People complain and they look around.
May take a little longer now. They're left sitting in the dark.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WEST WING LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby and Congressman Shallick are on the dais of Capitol Beat. Ginger is in the crowd.

Dialogues.Line: Excuse me...
I don't...

Excuse me. But this White House uses the first amendment to protect flag burning, to protect pornography, to ban school prayer. Why when the second amendment clearly says that the federal government will not infringe upon a citizens...
Because it doesn't...
...right to keep and bear arms...
It doesn't barely say that.
Toby!
In fact it doesn't say that at all. The only way it says that at all is if you remove some words from it.
Oh, look. Will you...?

It says a well-regulated militia, being necessary for the security of the free state... the government shall not infringe. The words regulated and militia are in the first sentence. I don't think the Framer's were thinking of three guys in a Dodge Durango.
Well, you don't really know what the Framers were thinking, do you?

No. But I do know that if you combine the populations of Great Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark and Australia you've got a population roughly the size of the United States. We had 32,000 gun deaths last year and they had 112. Do you think it's because Americans are more homicidal by nature? Or do you think it's because those guys have gun control laws.

We're going to talk to some people and hear answers to that question. You're watching a special expanded edition of Capital Beat coming live from the West Wing of the White House. We'll have more after this.
We're out.
Toby... Ginger gestures and Toby removes his mic.
Mark, I'm gonna sit out the next segment.
Yeah?
Yeah, I've got to see someone. I'll get you a body. [follows Ginger] Has she been waiting long? Ginger No.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Abbey is pacing in the office as Toby enters.

Dialogues.Line: I'm sorry I'm late.
It's fine.
I was on the air.
I wanted to ask you...
Mrs. Bartlet...
Toby.
Excuse me for interrupting. I just wanted to remind you that there's press coming in and out of this area. [looks around]
Are you under the impression I'm going to have a fit of some kind?
No, ma'am.
So, what's the deal? He gets a highway and you name a park after him?
Mrs. Bartlet, the Blue Ribbon Commission...
The Blue Ribbon Commission is swell. I am not talking about the Blue Ribbon Commission, and you know it. And don't talk to me like I'm 'other people'. You've never done that. Toby stares at her.
It was the language.
Mrs. Bartlet?

The draft I read said, "The first fiscal priority of the government must be, will be ensuring social security and Medicare." Now how did that turn into "boldly setting aside our partisan blinders"? Is the White House considering new options?
Look...
Raising retirement age?
Abbey...
And how did school uniforms get in such a prominent spot?
It was in a section on education reform, Abbey and considering other options doesn't mean we're caving on retirement age and you know it. So, what was your concern with the language?
The draft said, "Our commitment to the full benefits promised to Americas greatest generation is absolute." I was there when you wrote that.
And our commitment is still absolute. We're open to new ideas and that's what it said.
Oh, please...

Believe me, we gave Republicans plenty to be pissed about... the surplus, missile defense, capital gains. And I was just on TV for the 900th time and alienated gun owners... to say nothing of people who own Dodge Durango's. So, what exactly was your problem with the language?
It seemed...
Abbey...
I was just thrown by the last minute changes. [looks uncomfortable] You should get back on T.V. [walks out]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. CAROL'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Carol stands in her office as C.J. walks by.

Dialogues.Line: He's here?
Yeah. Waiting inside C.J.'S OFFICE is Officer JACK SLOANE.
Officer Sloane.
Yes, ma'am.
I'm C.J. Cregg. [They shake hands.] I'm the White House Press Secretary and I'm sorry to get you out of the party.
Aw, it's all right.
I'm sorry to be abrupt but I'm racing the clock a little bit. [They sit.] Could you tell me what happen 17 years ago with a suspect named Walter Tapus? Sloane looks uncomfortable.
I can access the information through the FBI and call the Wayne county DA...
Do I need to have my lawyer here?
I don't think you do but if you'd like to call...

No. There was an armed robbery in progress. I was pursuing Walter Tapus on foot through a series of fence in storage areas behind a warehouse. I apprehended him and tried to cuff him during which he broke my hand and nose.
So you fractured his leg.
I didn't fracture his leg.
He said you kicked him repeatedly while he was handcuffed.
He was suing the city for $5 million. What possible motivation would he have had to lie?
Officer...

He was 19 years old. 6'2"...190 pounds. And he won 2 bronze medals at the State High School Track and Field Championships. Miss Cregg, look at me. Do you think there's any way I catch up to this guy if his leg isn't fractured already? [firmly] It didn't happen.
Why didn't you tell anybody this was on your record when you were invited here?
I just assumed... I mean... 'cause of what happened over the weekend at the elementary school...
Yeah. [looks down]
I assumed it was okay now... That... I was okay. I didn't think it was all gonna come up again. Does the press know?
No, but I have to tell them.
Why?
Cause they'll find out and I have to stay ahead of the pitch. If I issue it in a brief statement then it looks like we're not trying to hide anything and I get to control the story for a while.
[looks stricken] There is no story.
Officer...
The DA couldn't bring a case. The civil suit was dismissed.
The President pointed to you as an example.
[plaintively] I AM an example.
It's a story.
Cause you're giving it to them.
Cause they'll find out about it anyway.
You don't know that.
Yes, I do.
My... My, um... My wife and kids are back at the party.
You should go back there. They stand.
Yeah. [turns away]
Don't talk to anybody about this.
Yeah.
I wish you had said something to us before. Sloane stands in the doorway.
Yeah. I just assumed. Thought it was okay now. Sloane leaves with C.J. standing.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NATIONAL STRATEGIES GROUP - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Donna sits in the dark talking into the phone. She scribbles into her pad by flashlight. Josh sits nearby with his head in his hands.

Dialogues.Line: Okay. [hangs up] Good news. [reads from her pad] The Potomac Electric Power Company says the outage was caused by a 13,000-volt cable that caught fire in a building on M Street and Wisconsin.
How is that good news?
[shines the flashlight in his face] Well, we have hard information now.
When's the power going back on?
That information isn't available at this time.
Donna...
I can tell you that [reads from pad] the outage is affecting some 2,000 customers and it was likely started when a repairman mis-sliced... [shakes head] something...
Call Sam. [yells] I want the numbers!
You know Josh, everyone else is having fun with this. Donna dials the phone. Joey and Kenny sneak up.
You're the only one who's having fun with this. Nobody else is having fun with this. Joey bumps into Josh.
Boo! [laughing]
Are those numbers safe?
Yes.
Are we gonna be able to make the West Coast calls?
It depends on when the power goes on.
When's that gonna be?
Hey!
Do I look like Electricity Girl?
No.
[into phone] I'm thinking of leading everyone in song.
Is that Sam?
Yeah.
Give it to me. [grabs the phone and stalks away]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NORTH ENTRANCE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam stands in the hallway.

Dialogues.Line: Sam.
What's going on?
The power's down.
I know.
We're five minutes away from an East Coast sample. We got nothing west of Indiana, Illinois...
You need anything?
A lightning bolt, a key, and a kite.
Donna told me to tell you you should ask out Joey Lucas.
Hey, can I tell ya Donna's been acting kind of...
I gotta go. Sam abruptly hangs up. Bartlet, staffers and Secret Service Agents enter
[into hand mic] We're in.
[walks up] Sir.
How's it going? [They shake hands.]
They lost power at National Strategies.
I heard.
Well done, Mr. President.
[to staffer] Thank you. [to Sam] Listen you scored big on some of the stuff I fought you on. [acknowledges staffers as they walk by]
Yes, and I know a way you can repay me.
Repay you for what?
For you being wrong in the face of me being right.
[waves] I owe you money for that?
Oh, not money, Sir.
I owe you anything for that?
Great job, Mr. President!
[waving] Thank you.

Ainsley Hayes has been working here for 3 months and she's still a little frightened of meeting you. If you should happen you run into her in the halls perhaps you could make a point... [They stop walking] ...of introducing yourself and welcoming her personally.
Don't you already get paid? Charlie walks up.
Randomly in the hallways in the next few days you two are bound to be in the same place at the same time. Would just...
Mr. President...
[to Charlie] Hang on. [to Sam] Is there anything in particular you'd like me to say?

[dives right in] I think if you said something along the lines of "You know, a lot of people assumed you were hired because you're a blonde, republican sex kitten and they were obviously wrong". [nodding] And to keep up the good work.
[smiling] That's really good.
[realizes what he said] Yeah.
Mr. President.
Yeah. Bartlet nods and walks away with Charlie. Sam looks embarrassed and walks off. Bartlet looks back over his shoulder at Sam. He walks in the OUTER OVAL OFFICE to find Leo stnading there.
Mr. President.
What's going on with the police officer?
C.J.'s looking into it.
We're going to get knocked off the story by a...
The cop isn't what's going to knock us off the story. Leo opens the door for Bartlet.
What is? They enter THE OVAL OFFICE. Assembled inside are the players from the Situation Room.
We have a situation in Colombia.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet stands behind the couch reading a brief.

Dialogues.Line: They can be identified as drug agents? DEA Rep They were dressed as civilians but they've got DEA badges.
Yeah, they may have blown their cover.
Sir.
Mickey, how do we know they're still alive?
Human sources paid by the Colombian National Police confirm they're in a Sierre AF outpost.
And they kill our guys unless Santos releases Juan Aguilar from a prison in Bogot..
Which the Columbian government isn't going to do.
It doesn't matter.
Why not?
Affronte doesn't care about Juan Aguilar and how long he stays in jail. They want to kill these guys.
I don't think...

They want to drag their bodies through the streets. These people provide 70% of the world's cocaine. They have 122,000 hectares of coca. The Puente Maya region alone produced 400 million dollars in cocaine for them last year. The government has no control over the region. There is no law and they're gonna shoot these guys in the head and then have a parade.
If they wanted to kill them they'd already be dead.
Robbie...
Ok. Mr. President, this plan is called Cassiopeia. [hands Bartlet a brief] Three M-860 Blackhawks, two MM-6 Littlebirds and an AC-130 Gunship. Bartlet sits.
Each Blackhawk has 10 Delta commandos from Special Forces.
How long?
Five to seven minutes.
How many Affronte casualties?
Do you care? Bartlet looks at Leo for a long time.
[shaking head] No.
Mr. President, I want to strongly urge that we continue negotiating.
You think we're headed for Vietnam?
I think if we make an armed attack, Affronte will hit back.
How?

I think they will bomb our embassy. I think they will kill Diplomats. I think they will kill citizens in captivity. All of which will require is a military response. It could unify the drug lords. It could destabilize the region. Yes, I think it could lead to a war.
Lead to a war? We're in a war. We're sending people down there to fight a war on drugs. These guys aren't hostages, they're prisoners.
How long is it going to take Special Forces to mobilize?
There are 141's right now on the way to Tres Encinas. We can give them a go order in three hours.
[looks at his watch] Well then, I want our people to keep talking to Nelson Guerra. But in three hours in want to be ready to kick in the back door.
Yes sir.
Leo, I'd like the Senior Staff. Would you round them up?
Yes, sir. Bartlet rises to leave. Everyone stands.
[to Leo] I'll be wandering the halls.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Sir. Bartlet leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NATIONAL STRATEGIES GROUP - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Donna and Josh sit in the darkness. Joey and Kenny sit on the couch. Outside, a Power Truck can be seen driving slowly down the street.

Dialogues.Line: You know what I'm surprised about?
[long pause] What?
We haven't seen a lot of looting.
Yeah.
Usually in these cases you see a lot more looting...
Yeah.
...general civil unrest...
Yeah. [looks at his watch]
...people get on each other's nerves.
[looks at her] Okay. Frustrated, Josh rises and walks over to the couch.
Joey... can I ask you what may be a silly question?
Sure.
It's not possible is it for us to just open one of these computers with a screwdriver and get the numbers that are in there, right? The phone rings.
Why would you think that would be a silly question?
I WANT THESE NUMBERS!
[walks up with the cell phone] Josh?
Yeah.
It's Sam. [hands him the phone]
Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam stands in the office.

Dialogues.Line: You gotta come back.
What's going on?
I don't know. Leo wants everybody back. Leave Joey and Donna for a while.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NATIONAL STRATEGIES GROUP - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: I'll be right there. Josh hangs up and walks back to DONNA. Sam looks momentarily confused and steps out of his office. CUT TO INT. COMMUNICATION'S BULLPEN - CONTINUOUS Ginger sits at her desk.
Ginger?
Yeah.
Isn't Ainsley Hayes supposed to be meeting me now?
She's in her office.
Isn't she supposed to be meeting me here?
She needs to meet you in her office.
Why?
She can't wear her pants. Sam looks confused and walks off.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AINSLEY'S OFFICE- NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Ainsley is dancing and singing to "Blame It on the Bossa Nova". She dressed in a White House robe. She doesn't see Sam slowly walk up the hall.

Dialogues.Line: [singing and dancing] Blame it on the bossa nova with its magic spell... Sam stands outside the door as she continues to sing and dance.
Blame it on the bossa nova that he did so well...
[slowly enters] Ainsley! Ainsley turns, laughs, and continues singing and dancing.
Oh, it all began with just a little dance [tightens the robe] but soon it ended up a big romance.
Well, I hardly know where to start.
I was feeling so good after my segment that I went into the sculpture garden. [smiles]
You guys... really, there's a wet paint sign on the bench.
My assistant went to get me clothes. [dances]
Why are you moving like that?
I'm Blaming it on the Bossa Nova!
[laughing] Okay.

I know what you mean about the adrenaline high. [picks up a drink] I think I've definitely got it. Plus, the bartender made me a Pink Squirrel Suzy. I'm not the teetotaler you think I am. [takes a drink]
Is there any alcohol in that at all?
There's a dash of cr'me d'cacao, my friend. She offers him a drink as she dances. Sam laughs and blushes.
I came down here to tell you...
Oh, dance with me, Sam! Ainsley dances up to him. He looks bashful. She dances away and starts singing.
...a family, Bartlet slowly walks up the hall.

And when our kids ask... Ainsley turns and screams as she sees Bartlet standing in the doorway. Her drink goes flying. Sam turns towards the doorway. He turns back to Ainsley with an embarrassed expression.
[casually] What's up? Ainsley stands horrified.
Mr. President!
I never even knew we HAD a nightclub down here. Sam looks embarrassed.
Oh, my gosh! AINSLEY quickly turns off the radio.
Mr. President, I don't believe you've met Ainsley Hayes. Ainsley gathers her dignity and tightens the robe.

Yeah. Ainsley, I wanted to say hello and to you know... mention "a lot of people assumed you were hired because you're a blonde, republican sex kitten" and well, they're obviously wrong. Keep up the good work.
Yes, sir.
[to Sam] You know we're meeting?
Yes sir. Bartlet nods and leaves.
That could have been worse. Ainsley looks nauseous.
No, probably not. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WEST WING LOBBY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. is back on the Capital Beat dais, fully clothed.

Dialogues.Line: And take us behind the scenes. What are the President and the First Lady doing right now?
Well, the receptions still going on. I don't know if you can hear the music. The President and Mrs. Bartlet are likely to stay up late with friends.
All right. We're staying up late too. Maybe we'll be invited to the party. C.J. laughs.
We're going to take a break and come right back.
We're out.
How you holding out?
You got a second?
Yeah. They remove their mics and step behind stage.
I've laid off it all night because we've done some things together and I didn't want to ambush you, but...
You know about Sloane.
Yeah.
Mark...
Mark, I talked to the guy. And before the stampede begins... Toby stands in the doorway.
...please give me a chance...
C.J. looks at Toby them back at Mark.
Let me talk to you before...
C.J. looks back at Toby.
Leo Mc Garry would like you to meet an old friend of his.
Mark, give me 20 minutes before you break the story.
Why?
We've done things together.
I'm looking at my watch. C.J. runs out. She and Toby walk off.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE KITCHEN - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Party music and conversation can be heard as Bartlet enters the kitchen. Chefs and stewards work preparing food. Seated at a counter is Abbey, eating a sandwich. Bartlet approaches her.

Dialogues.Line: Hey.
Hey.
They said you were in here.
Yeah, just for a minute.
[looks over at the kitchen staff] Fellas... As they exit, Bartlet nods to them. Abbey avoids his gaze.
You're mad at me.
Jed, you know what? I'm not your mommy.
Abbey, so I indicated we were open to new ideas. How did I fail you this time?
You didn't fail anyone, Jed. They've been giving you some pretty decent style points. Bartlet looks sharply at her. Abbey avoids his glare.
I have a meeting. [turns and starts to walk out]
At what point in the process did you decide not to mention the Violence Against Women Act in tonight's address?
[turns back] Things had to be cut.

Jane Robinson, by the way, is the name of the woman I made the check out to. It wasn't cashed because she framed it. Charlie tracked her down in a Battered Women's Shelter and that's what made me think of the Violence Against Women Act.
To make a 90 minutes speech into an 80 minutes speech things had to go.
[angry] Good thing it didn't have to be any shorter or school uniforms wouldn't have made the cut.
Abbey.
We had a deal!
Right now...
You made a promise. We made a deal!
Abbey.
When did you decide you were going to run for a second term?
[looks at her with surprise] That's not what tonight's...
That's ALL that tonight's speech was about. [long pause] You kicked off your reelection campaign and I'm sitting here eating a sandwich cause we had a deal! [holds back tears]
That was three years ago.
[nods] Yeah.
I have Special Forces headed to Columbia on ready alert. They're waiting for an order in a little less than hours.
What happened? Charlie enters.
Affronte took five DEA Agents hostage in Puente Mayo...
Mr. President.
Yeah?
The Senior Staff's together.
I'll be right there.
Yes, sir. [leaves]
Abbey...
[stands] No, you've got to focus right now.
All right. [sighs] I've got to go.

I stay up with you. Bartlet looks at her as he walks away. Abbey stands for a moment then exits. In the entry way she pauses, straightens her hair, and composes herself before she exits to the crowded RECEPTION HALL, and mingles with the guests.

Welcome back. If you're just joining us we're here live tonight from the West Wing of the White House with an all star panel. We're talking about the State of the Union and it appears it's a blockbuster. Claire Wilburn joins us now from the Chicago Sun-Times...

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
